loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa B. is a married woman who lives in Hacienda  Maruja, Brgy. 9, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two businesses.  One business sells dried fish and the other rice. Her husband, Joben B., who is 38 years-old, works as a laborer and also helps with his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are aged 13 to 18 years -old. 

In 2003, Marissa joined Kiva partner NWTF-Project Dungganon because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past ten loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marissa has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 11th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to expand her rice and dried fish businesses so that she can continue to save for the future. Marissa B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the poverty alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org in order to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria B. is from the village of Cabisera 5, Baribad. She is 51 years-old and married with three adult children. To make a living, Maria owns and operates a business raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Maria has been engaged in her business for over 31 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Maria joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Maria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia  S. is a widow who lives in Brgy. Tuguis, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  a General store and a Rice Retailing business. 

Delia  joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her 23 past loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Delia  has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 14,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 24th loan, she is again borrowing PHP 29,000 which she intends to use to purchase more stock for her general (sari-sari) store and rice retailing businesses so that she can continue to save up for their future.  The profit she will earn will be part of her savings.  Delia  S. is a 'Dungganon' woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria S. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 47 years old. Gloria is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Gloria owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She says she is thankful to have a source of income and hopes for her farm to grow more.

Gloria joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the second loan taken out by Gloria from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and improve their living conditions. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.name: Kiyal

texts.en:
Kiyal J. is a resident of Tup, a nice small town in the Isykul region. Kiyal is 36 and married. She has four daughters, three daughters are at school and the youngest one is not yet. Five years ago with an initial investment of 10000 soms, Kiyal bought a bull and since that moment she started to breed cattle. 

Her husband works in the police and when he has free time he tries to help Kiyal with her activity. Selling some cattle after fattening, Kiyal makes 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase two bulls in order to increase the number of cattle she has. In the future she plans to build a shed and expand her business to have enough money to continue to support her daughters.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase two bulls

loans.name: Urmat

texts.en:
Urmat M. is a 62-year-old villager who lives in Kamishanovka village. She is married with seven adult children. The youngest son is serving in the army. 

To make a living, Urmat is occupied with cattle breeding.  In the beginning, when she milked cows and sold the milk to her customers, she earned about 210 Kyrgyz Soms daily; today, this sum is nearly equal to 400 Kyrgyz Soms a day. Also, she deals in fattening up of bull-calves. She has been engaged in her business for 30 years and earns approximately 7,000 Kyrgyz Soms a month for these activities. Her main helper is her husband who supports her and maintains the farm. 

Urmat is a very energetic and optimistic woman. In spite of finishing only secondary school, she has been able to make her business successful. Now Urmat is requesting a loan of 60,000 Kyrgyz Soms to buy one milk cow and two bull-calves. That allows her further development of her household and business.

In the future, Urmat plans to make good living conditions for her son and hold his wedding.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population.  Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Zina's Group

texts.en:
Zina U. is the leader of this group. She is 38 and married. She has a daughter and three sons. The first son studies at university and the others are at school. 

Zina works in a pharmacy and her husband is a tractor driver. A year ago the husband’s sister suggested that Zina should open a pharmacy, and with an initial investment of 10,000 soms she started her business activity. With money received from the loan, Zina wants to purchase a variety of medicines in order to increase the turnover of her business.  In the future she plans to expand her business, contribute some money to her older son’s wedding, and save money to be able to pay for her children’s education. 

Dokturkan T., 53, is married. She has two sons and two daughters. The older son went to work to Russia to earn some money, two daughters are married and live separately with their families, and the youngest son studies at university. A year ago with the initial investment of 10,000 soms Dokturkan purchased nine sheep for breeding. Selling some sheep after fattening, she makes 3000 soms per month. With money received from the loan Dokturkan wants to increase the number of her livestock and purchase five more sheep. 

Sabyrkul E. is the treasurer of the group. She is 50 and married. She has three sons and two daughters. The sons study at university and the daughters are at school. Sabyrkul works in a pharmacy and her husband is a private driver.  In order to cover the family expenses, Sabyrkul and her husband started to breed cattle. Selling some cattle after fattening, they make 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan Sabyrkul wants to purchase two bulls in order to increase the number of cattle she has. In the future she plans to build a bigger house and purchase a vehicle.

Guluipa K. is 45 and married.  She has three sons and a daughter.  The oldest son went away to work in Russia; the other two sons are at school and the daughter is not yet.  A year ago Guluipa got a loan in the amount of 5000 soms and started to breed livestock. And now selling some sheep after fattening, she makes 3000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase five more sheep for breeding.  In the future she plans to increase the number of livestock, purchase a vehicle, and save some money to be able to pay for her children’s education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.name: Nurbubu's Group

texts.en: Nurbubu K. is the leader of this group. She is 44 and married with a daughter and a son. The son is married and lives separately with his own family and the daughter studies at school. Nurbubu and her husband have been breeding livestock for fifteen years and every month they sell some sheep to cover the family expenses. With the money received from the loan Nurbubu wants to purchase more sheep in order to increase the number of their livestock. In the future she plans to build a shed and start repairing her house. Taalaibek S. is 23 and divorced. In order to make money, he works as a taxi driver using his own car. Three years ago, with an initial investment of 20,000 soms, he started to breed livestock. Then he sold all the livestock and purchased his vehicle. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase auto parts to repair his car. Farida T., 33, is married with a daughter and a son, both of whom attend school. Five years ago, with an initial investment of 8,000 soms, she bought three sheep and then resold them after fattening. In five years, Farida has increased the number of her livestock to fifteen. She applied for the loan because she wants to improve her living conditions and purchase furniture. In the future she plans to open a kiosk near the house and start selling convenience goods. Kumushai J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 51 and married with three sons and two daughters. All the children are married and live separately with their families. Ten years ago, with an initial investment of 5,000 soms, Kumushai opened a kiosk and began to sell convenience goods. But then her husband suggested she start selling meat, because nobody in their village does that. When Kumushai started to sell meat, she noticed that the demand for meat is high enough and she makes good money. She applied for the loan because she needs to purchase sheep. In the future she plans to expand her business and then start repairing her house. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. loans.name: Bermet's Group

texts.en: Bermet T. is the leader of this group. She is 28 and married with two daughters, both of whom are of preschool age (under 7). Bermet works as the supervisor of the electricity station. Two years ago, with an initial investment of 20,000 soms, Bermet bought two cows for breeding. Now she has applied for the loan because she wants to increase the number of her cattle and to purchase cattle for breeding. Shahra S. is 33 and divorced with two daughters; the first daughter is at school and the second is not yet schooling. With money received from the loan she wants to improve their living conditions and purchase a washing machine. Mirdolot A., 22, is a dentist. A year ago, with an initial investment of 12,000 soms, he bought some farm animals for breeding. Now, he has a cow and six sheep. Sometimes if he needs money he can sell some sheep to cover his personal expenses. With the money received from the loan he wants to purchase cattle for breeding. In the near future he plans to get married. Kanyshai O. is the treasurer of the group. She is 21 and works as an operator in the Department of Social Defense. A year ago, with an initial investment of 4,000 soms, she bought two goats for breeding and now she has four goats. With the money received from the loan she wants to purchase some farm animals in order to increase the number of her livestock. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.name: Rose Marie

texts.en:
Rose Marie L. is a married woman who lives in Hugno, Brgy. Manalad, Ilog, Negros Occidental. She earns her living with farming and hog raising businesses. Her husband Efren, 59 years old, works as a farmer to earn a living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 4 children who are 13 to 19 years old.

Rose Marie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rose Marie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.

This time, for her 17th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 which she intends to use to sustain her farming and hog raising businesses so that she can continue to save for their future and for the education of their children.

Rose Marie L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To fund business operations.

Luz joined CEVI to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Luz is requesting her second loan, for 6000 PHP, which she will use to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs. She also plans to buy feed for the pigs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About CEVI

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia R. is a 62-year old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures:  a general store and a fishing business. She lives in Purok Ipil-ipil, Barangay Bulanon, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1995 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and fishing businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. 

Lucia is now borrowing PHP 21000 so that she could  purchase additional inventory for her general store and buy materials to make more fishing nets. This will be her 14th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Lucia aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie M. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 48 years old. Tessie is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Tessie owns & operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Tessie says she works hard so she could help provide food for her family and proper education for her children. She hopes to have all her children finish college someday and hopefully for them to have a bright future.

Tessie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This will be the second loan taken out by Tessie from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and to improve their living conditions. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. loans.name: Sous

Sous A. owns a piece of land that he inherited from his grandparents. He grows different kinds of crops on his land such as rubber and potato crops. Hi children help with family financial responsibilities by working as requirement laborers. His wife appears on the left of the photo. She works with him in the farm field. Sous A. will be using a loA. he requested to buy a plot of neighbor's farmland, where he will plant new crops for extra income.

She was introduced to KADET by business partners. She wants to use her loan to improve her salon by buying more improved machines.

She hopes to grow her business and to give the best services to her customers and improve the standard of living for her family.

loans.name: Esmeraldo

texts.en:
Esmeraldo P. is a widower who lives in Magatas, Sibulan, Negros Oriental. He earns his living by operating 2 business ventures:  Farming and general store businesses.  

Esmeraldo joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because he aspired for something better for his family. With the help of his past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Esmeraldo has been incrementally lifting his family out of poverty by the sweat of his brow. His previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped him earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for his 11th cycle loan, he is borrowing PHP 25,000 which he intends to use to purchase fertilizer for his citrus (calamansi) plantation so that he could continue to save up for future investments. Esmeraldo P. is a Dungganon man who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of his dreams.

loans.name: Nyambirizi Bahingi Barungi, Bushenyi Group

texts.en: In village called Nyambirizi, Bushenyi, there is a determined lady K. Joselyne, aged 35 years. She is a go-getter businesswoman who has been dealing in general merchandise, owning a retail shop. This stickler of hard work is also a widowed mother of 5. She has basked in the career graces of her business for the last 4 years. With this experience behind her, she has managed to subdue most of the uncertain adversities that have threatened to play havoc with her business. Each month her business generates a profit of 20,000 Ugandan shillings. This, to all intents and purposes, is a low figure. What has played into her hands, as she operates her business, has been her exceptional skill in customer relations. As it is now, she is taking a long view with an aim of maximizing her small profits. She figures this loan will come in significantly handy in helping her buy more inventory as currently she sells small household items.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for business for resale.

loans.name: Gunjilmaa

texts.en: Gunjilmaa O. is 31 years old and lives with her parents in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia in a ger- a traditional nomadic housing tent. Gunjilmaa operates a clothing trading business out of a rented stall at the local market called Han Talst. Her parents are retired and stay at home. She started her business in 2008 and has found success in her trade. She has used her earnings to support her family. After trading a variety of clothing, she has decided to expand her sales types by selling bags and hats, which would enable her to increase her business revenues. She is a modest person and, in the future, Gunjilmaa hopes to continue her success and to grow her business. She is working hard and trying her best to repair the house that her family lives in together. This would help her parents live more comfortably than previously. Gunjilmaa is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to import more clothes from China for her business.

loans.use: To import more clothes.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her tailoring, house rental and sari-sari store businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10000. 

Violeta is now borrowing PHP 29500 so that she can purchase more materials for her tailoring business. This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 29500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Violeta aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Bwanda Bakyara Kwetungura, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
A supportive, hard working and widowed, B. Lydia, aged 54 years, is a mother of 7 children. She has been operating a retail shop business from Bwanda Trading centre in Rukungiri. In the shop, she is selling general merchandise especially for home use, such as: basins, jerrycans, buckets, grocery, sugar, salt and more. She started this business 10 years ago from her previous farming enterprise. At the end of every month she is able to pocket profits to the tune of 185,000 Ugandan shillings. 

Her main drawback has been having too little stock in her business, therefore not matching  the purchasing rate of her customers. Lydia is seeking a loan that she figures will help her stock more goods that will satisfy the customers’ high demand. She feel that this will also transform her enterprise into a big enterprise. 

Being very committed to the business with good customer care, she hopes to increase her sales revenue. This will bring about a transformation for her business and enable her to achieve a self sustaining life. She hopes to cater to her family's requirements, especially to fulfill her dream of educating her grandchildren. She further looks at buying herself a plot of land where she can set up her own business premises.

loans.use: To purchase of more inventory for business.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Susan Wanjiru

texts.en:
Susan is 38 years old and has two children in secondary school. She is married to John Muturi who operates a taxi within Nairobi city centre. She has been running her business for about six years and has an income of about KES 80,000.

She wants to use the loan to buy more inventory for her shop. She will use the anticipated profit to renovate the rental houses she has. Her dream is to have a stable income, through which she can meet all of her family's basic needs.

loans.use: To increase inventory of products like beans, rice, and mung beans

loans.name: Leang

texts.en:
Mr. Leang S. (in photo) is 50 years old, and his wife, Mrs. Phally Nang, is 45 years old. They have been married since 1986 and have six children: two sons and four daughters. One of the children is married and lives outside the family home, two are garment factory workers, one is a construction worker, and another one attends school. Mr. Leang S. and his wife live in a small village across the Mekong River approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.
 
Leang and his wife are farmers. They grow gourds and cucumbers on their farmland in the village. The couple does not have enough capital to purchase seed, fertilizer, and pesticide to maintain their farm. Leang is asking for his first loan in the amount of $700 to provide capital to purchase these items.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer, and pesticide

loans.name: Bathorol

texts.en: Bathorol G. is a 39-year-old  woman who lives with her husband and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent. With the help of her family, Bathorol currently operates a meat trading business. She purchases meat in bulk and resells it from a rented stall at retail prices in Han Talst, one of the biggest markets in her town. Bathorol started her meat trading business in 2000. She has been operating there for 10 years and has gained much knowledge and experience, which makes her a good supplier to her customers. Bathorol is a tidy, creative, and hard-working woman who wishes to expand her business into a small food store with her earnings. She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more meat and meat products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase meat

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en: Elisa P. is from the village of North Park Area, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 42 years old. Elisa is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Elisa sells livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling broiler chickens. Elisa has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Elisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elisa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock to sell in future. This will be the first loan taken out by Elisa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. loans.name: Sophat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophat S. (pictured) is 41 years old and her husband, Mr. Pharet Chea, is 37 years old. They have been married since 1993 and have two daughters. One of them is in school and another one is still young. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh.   

Sophat and her husband are garment-factory workers. She is asking for her first loan of $1,200 to renovate the house where she lives and build a restroom for the family’s use.

loans.use: To renovate the house where she lives and build a restroom for the family’s use

loans.name: Lourdesita

texts.en: Lourdesita L. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Prenza, Brgy. Balamban, Toledo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: vegetable vending and a carenderia (food vending) business. Her husband Albino L., who is 63 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have eight children who are 24 to 40 years old. Lourdesita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lourdesita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 12,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her eighth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000. She intends to use it to purchase raw materials for her businesses so that she could continue to save up for the future and to support her grandchildren's educations. Lourdesita L. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Miss. Savoeun S., 39, is single (shown in the picture), and lives with her elderly parents and sisters a suburb of Phnom Penh. She has been a garment factory worker for ten years. 

Savoeun does not have her own transportation, which costs her a lot of money in traveling expenses. So, she is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorcycle so that she can drive to work. She also will use a part of her loan to concrete her house foundation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting and to concrete her house foundation.

loans.name: Titus Ndugi

texts.en:
Titus is a 21 year old single man. He buys maize, sweet potatoes and groundnuts, which he cooks and sells to his customers.  He has been in the business for a period of about two years. He gets a monthly income of KES 20,000 per month.

He wants to use his loan to improve on his business by buying more maize and groundnuts to sell. He hopes to expand his business and be a distributor.

loans.use: To buy more maize, sweet potatoes and tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Lun

texts.en: Mrs. H. is a 35-year-old widowed woman who currently resides in the middle of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She is blessed with three kids, one of whom is employed in a garment factory and the other two are students. H. is a sewing laborer in the garment industry. She started her job more than a year ago. She also spends time at home to take care of the kids and to do household work. H. has another piece of village land where she plans to build a few rooms for rent, from which she will get extra profit. She isn't able to make her goal possible because she doesn't have money yet. To help overcome this obstacle, H. decided to seek a Kiva loan in the amount of $1200 for the propose of building a few rooms where she will rent to garment workers for a monthly fee.

loans.use: To build a few rooms where she rents.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn A. is from the village of Tumbao, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 42 years old. Jocelyn is married and has 8 school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Sonim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sonim S. (pictured here), and her husband, Mr. Socheat Yum, have been married since 2001 and have three young daughters. All of the children are in school. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh, about twenty kilometers from the city. 

Mrs. Sonim S. has been a garment factory worker for more than ten years. Her husband is a teacher. The couple has plot of the land and they want to operate a rice-growing business. But, they have no time and they are busy with their work.  

For this reason, Sonim is applying for her second loan of $1,200 to hire the fellow villagers to grow rice and to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her rice farm.

loans.use: To use for growing rice.

loans.name: Ayush

texts.en:
Ayush C. is 47 years old. She lives with her husband and two daughters, ages 22 and 25, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her two daughters help Ayush with her sewing business, while her husband is handicapped and stays at home. 

Ayush operates a business of sewing traditional Mongolian clothes, such as deels (long coats), as well as making cotton cases for mugs, caps and snuff bottles. She began her business in 2008 and has since become established in the local business community. 

Ayush supplies her embroidered products to shops where the items can be sold to tourists. She hopes to become even more successful so that she can provide for her family in the future.

Her family is building a house in their yard and she hopes to one day open her own small tailoring shop. Ayush is a hardworking woman who is requesting a 1,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan so that she can purchase more fabric and materials and a sewing machine for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more fabric and materials

loans.name: Houn

texts.en:
Mr. Houn H. (shown in the photo), 56, and his wife, Mrs. Touch Nhoung, 55, have been married since 1979. They have eight children: four sons and four daughters. Five of them married and live outside the family home, one attends school and other two have full-time employment in Phnom Penh City. They are living across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Houn has been a fisherman for 15 years, while his wife sells the fish that her husband caught. Houn is asking for a loan of $200 to add to his own money to purchase a motorcycle for his children to drive to work.

loans.use: To add to his own money to purchase a motorbike for his children to drive to work

loans.name: Sophoin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophoin V., 29, and her husband, Mr. Vanh Sroeun, 31, married in 2001 and have two young children (pictured above). The family lives across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sophoin sells fruits and her husband is a taxi driver. Besides these businesses, the couple also grows rice and lotus on their farmland in the village.

Sophoin is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase a water-pumping machine to spray her farm.

loans.use: To purchase a water-pumping machine to spray her farm

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 44-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She has 5 children, 2 of whom are still attending school. 10 years ago, she started working at the occupation she really likes, wedding and speciA. ceremonies organizer. Her work consists of arranging and organizing all the preparations related to the events in addition to making flower designs. Over the years, her work has developed and she has built a good business reputation. Today, she is requesting to borrow $600 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase designing merchandise and motifs. During the summer season, her work operation increases and she has to be prepared to be always recruiting clients.

Note: Based on the politicA. and sociA. challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF InternationA., Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the CentrA. Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financiA. institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financiA. services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financiA. services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To purchase designing merchandise and motifs.

loans.name: Hermenegilda

texts.en:
Hermenegilda F. is a married woman who lives in Barangay Pasil, Santander, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures:  pig fattening and an ice cream vending businesses. Her husband, Melchor F., who is 36 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living. They have 3 children who between 9 mos. and 9 yrs. old.

Hermenegilda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Hermenegilda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 17th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 15000, which she intends to use to purchase piglets to raise and the feed needed to raise them. She also intends to use some of the money as revolving funds for her ice cream business so that she can continue to save up for the education of her children. Hermenegilda F. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and feed.

He was introduced to Kadet by a staff member. He wants to use his loan to service and improve his car in order to offer better services to his clients.

With his profits he hopes to buy another car for taxi services.

loans.name: Khuy

texts.en: Mr. Khuy T. is a 52-year-old father of five children who are living at home. Khuy T. owns an old motorcycle that he uses to provide a taxi service, while his wife is a good homemaker who arranges a daily routine and takes care of the children. To help meet with the family financial crisis, three of his daughters are employed in the garment industry. Khuy T. lives in an older house which needs repairs, so Khuy T. will be using his first loan to mend and decorate his house. Mr. Khuy T. was not available when the photograph was taken so his wife is pictured instead.

loans.use: To mend and decorate their old house.

loans.name: Kyeizinga Women's, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
A determined and hard working M. Mary, widowed at a tender age with 6 children, is vibrant sounding in terms of agriculture businesses in Ntungamo. She owns a banana plantation and other agricultural farms that include; coffee growing and beans. Her businesses generate income to the family. This has seen her earn 25,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis.

Her main drawback has been a lack of funding to purchase mulch for her plantations. The lack of mulch has reduced the yields. Therefore this loan will help her improve her yields, in terms of banana produce, thus enable her to meet the customers’ high demands and also to increase her sales revenue. In turn, making her more able to meet the family's requirements in terms of tuition fees for her children’s needs and to live a more self-sustaining life.

loans.use: Towards buying fertilizer and mulches for the plantation.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie V. is a 47-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a fish vending business. She lives in Prk. Suyac, Barangay Taba-ao, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4000. Tessie is now borrowing PHP 16000 so that she can purchase more fish to sell. This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 13000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Tessie aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Abelardo

texts.en:
Abelardo S. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is 37 years old. Abelardo is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Abelardo owns & operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Abelardo has been engaged in his business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities. Abelardo also shared that he was able to put up a sari-sari store that his wife manages now. He hopes for their store to grow as well.

In February 2010, Abelardo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Abelardo has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Abelardo is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Abelardo from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.name: Gantuguldur

texts.en: Gantuguldur J. is 32 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in their own apartment, which she has purchased recently. Gantuguldur's husband helps with her sewing business and the daughter attends a primary school, while the son goes to a kindergarten in his district. She began her business in 1995 after working as a dressmaker for several years. At first, she sold her products herself out of a rented stall in Narantuul-the biggest and crowdest market of Ulaanbaatar. Now she has expanded her business with three employees and changed her workplace into a bigger and more convenient market called Sunday Plaza. She owns many different sewing machines and designs and sews the clothing according to her customers' tastes. Because of her beautiful designs and the quality craftsmanship of the clothes, Gantuguldur has a large, loyal customer base. She says, “All I want is to grow my business and to open a big manufacturing business”.  Gantuguldur is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a bigger-size stall at Sunday Plaza market.

loans.use: To purchase a bigger-size stall.

loans.name: Noem

texts.en: Mrs. C. is 22 years of age and a resident of Phnom Penh, where she has established a small family home with other members. She is a good housewife who either takes care of a young child or arranges a daily routine. C. always relies on the income from her husband who works as a machinery repairman. He has a few employees who help provide his service. The family is often affected by transportation problems as they have no vehicle. Therefore, C. has decided to seek a loan of $1200 USD in order to purchase a new motorcycle to provide transport for the family. (Mrs. C.'s husband is pictured above).

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle to provide transportation for the family.

loans.name: Kacerere Women's, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
If one subsists on agriculture like one determined T. Jacklyn has found out, you need enormous reserves of patience to succeed. That particular attribute has worked in her favor. She speaks with pride of how their 2 children can all attain education. Her proficiency in attending to the banana plantation for the last 25 years in Ntungamo, alongside the produce business of selling beans, ground nuts and more food stuffs, has brought her the fruits of economic development. 

In a month, she makes profits in the amount of 60,000 Ugandan shillings. The only major drawn back problem that has plagued her business, has been the persistent low banana market prices in villages and that she has no ready means of transporting her produce to bigger markets. It is her reckoning that this loan will come in handy in helping her enhance her banana plantations on a large scale through mulching and the buying of fertilizer.

loans.use: Towards buying mulch for the banana plantation.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey P. (shown in the photo), 34, and her husband, Mr. Sochea Tep, 38, have been married since 1996 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. All of them are attending school. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Srey has been a silk weaver for 21 years. Her husband has been driving a motor taxi for 2 years. She is asking for her first loan in the amount of $300 to purchase silk material for her business.

loans.use: To buy silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en:
Mwanaidi is a married woman with three children: two boys and a girl, all adults.She has been operating her business of selling Kikoi's (African wraps) and shoes for the last five years, from door to door and from home, to her neighbors and passersby.

With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase a bundle of Kikoi’s at a wholesale price and resale at a retail price. She earns her other source of income from her husband's income.

Mwanaidi faces the major challenge of seasonality and competition in her business. Her major goal is to have her own shop in the future and be a supplier to the entire community. She decided to work with Yehu so as to access loans to improve her business and earn a living. She lives at her own house with electricity, but no piped water. Her major monthly expenses are food, clothing and electricity.

loans.use: To purchase a bale of Kikoi's.

loans.name: Oyuntungalag

texts.en:
Oyuntungalag T. is 28 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Hovd province in western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger- a traditional housing tent. Her husband is a taxi driver while Oyunchimeg operates a food retailing business out of a small rented shop as well as working as a teacher in Hovd-Erdem Institute. She started her business in 2003. 

Over the years Oyuntungalag has worked hard to build a stable business operation and has gained much experience. Due to the insufficiency of the teacher's salary, she is focusing on her food retailing business and trying her best to earn more. Her business is very important to her and her family. She says, "My only wish is to enlarge the business and to purchase a bigger store than the current one." Oyuntungalag is a modest and hardworking woman. She is requesting a 400,000 MNT loan to purchase more products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more products.

loans.name: Sholpongul's Group

texts.en:
Sholpongul K. is the leader of the group. She is 47 and a widow. She has raised two daughters: the first daughter lives and works in Karakol and the second daughter is at school. A year ago, with the initial investment of 8000 soms, Sholpongul started to breed livestock. Selling sheep after fattening, she makes 3000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase three sheep for breeding. 

Jyrgalbek O., 48, is married. He has two daughters: the older daughter is married and lives separately with her family and the second daughter is at school. In order to make money, Jyrgalbek works on construction and his wife is a librarian. In 1998, with the initial investment of 5000 soms, Jyrgalbek started to breed cattle. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase a bull in order to increase the number of cattle. 

Shapagat T. is the treasurer of the group. She is 48 and married. She has five daughters and a son: the first daughter is married and lives separately with her family and the other children are at school. Twenty years ago, due to the child’s birth, Shapagat was given a cow as a present for such an event.  And since that moment Shapagat has been breeding cattle. She applied for the loan because she wants to purchase a bull to increase the number of cattle. 

Joldosh M., 54, is married. He has two daughters, the older daughter is married and lives separately with her family and the second daughter lives with the parents and helps them with housework. In order to make money, Joldosh purchases currants in the villages and then resells at the higher price in Bishkek. He has also been breeding cattle for ten years. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase a calf for breeding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase three sheep.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 24-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She is living with her parents and 2 siblings. In order to help with the family expenses, she has been working as a private teacher since 2005. Her income is very important to pay for university fees. She likes her occupation because she feels that she is helping the students to get the needed education. She has arranged a special room with all the education preparation to teach the students. Her story illustrates day-to-day preparations in trying to continue her education and running a business in parallel. Today, she is requesting to borrow $800 to purchase a laptop in order to facilitate her work preparation and to do more research.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To purchase a laptop.
