loans.name: Jargalsaihan

texts.en: Jargalsaihan R. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Hovd province, in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His elder daughter attends a local middle school, and his younger twins go to a local kindergarten. His wife takes care of their children. Jargalsaihan owns and operates his own wooden products business, specializing in ger parts, ger furniture, and other larger furniture pieces. He started his business in 2003 and most of his profits come from the sales of his wooden furniture, which is sold at a local market. All of his products are made with great care and attention to detail, which has earned him a reputation among his customers as a quality furniture provider. He would like to increase his sales so that he can afford to build a small shop. Jargalsaihan is a hardworking and modest person who is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood so that he can increase the number and variety of large furniture pieces.

loans.use: To purchase more wood

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 47-year-old widow woman living with her three children. After the death of her husband, she found herself alone and responsible for the three children. So she decided to operate this mini market in 2006 when she was widowed. The store was opened 10 years ago by her husband. And she was able to manage her grocery shop and make a profit for her family. She offers all types of food products, dairy products, breads, detergents etc. With the loan of US $1200 that she requested, she will be able to increase her store’s inventory. In the future, she expects her business will continue to grow in the coming year.
 
It is very common in Lebanon to find small supermarkets selling perishable and non-perishable goods. As members of the communities themselves, storeowners have a deep understanding of local consumer needs and can offer products that meet local demands. The strong network of community relationships are an important component of life in Lebanon, especially in smaller towns and villages.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To increase her store’s inventory

loans.name: Essohanam

texts.fr: M. est une femme mariée et mère d'un enfant. elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de  d'habits, elle a associé plus tard à cette activité le commerce de foulards pour accroître ses revenus. elle fait ce commerce de façon ambulante pour toucher plus de clients. ce premier crédit qu'elle sollicite à WAGES va lui permettre d'augmenter son stock avec une vingtaine d'habits et quelques foulards.
texts.en:
Mrs. M. is a married mother of one. She sells clothing for a living. To increase her income, she also began selling scarves. She is an itinerant vendor and this allows her to reach more customers. This is the first loan she has requested through WAGES and it will allow her to purchase 20 outfits and some scarves.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothing and scarves

loans.name: Yulduz

texts.ru: Худойкулова Юлдуз жительница города Турсунзаде. Возраст, 40 лет. Разведена, имеет 4 детей. Старший сын на заработках в России. Сама Юлдуз имеет среднее образование.  У нее магазин, где она продает продукты питания. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 11 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Yulduz K. lives in Tursun-zoda. She is 40 years old. Divorced, with four children. Her eldest son is working in Russia. Yulduz has received secondary education. She keeps a grocery store. She has been in this business for 11 years already. She is taking out a loan in order to increase her sales volume.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing her sales volume

loans.name: King Of Kings-Lugazi Group

texts.en: Running any kind of business is not for the faint-hearted. From the threshold, constant challenges can ominously look one in the face and if one does not have that strength of character, everything may go up in smoke. One lady with a wealth of good will who has withstood enormous operating cost challenges in her retail shop business in Buziika- Lugazi over the course of the last 12 years is 34-year-old N. Fatuma, a happily married mother of five. Her reputation, she says, was once at stake, given the bad rapport she had with relatives who often wanted free goods from her shop, against her will. She almost closed her shop and was thinking of relocating. This is a chequered passage anybody who operates a business will face. This business was setup with savings from her farming business. Weekly, her business generates 80,000 shillings, and with this loan, she reckons she will be able to make her business expand by leaps and bounds through the purchase of more goodies for her shop. She is looking at buying more cooking oil, tomatoes, soap and onions to resell.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil, tomatos, soap and onions to resell

loans.name: Lugazi Development Group

texts.en: Any lucrative business driving that roaring lucrative trade can be a springboard to financial success. This normally happens when those holding sway of that business never lose sight of their set objectives in the course of operating. One person who has seen a flood of success in her business is 34-year-old N. Florence, a good-natured divorced mum of two buoyant children. To win her spurs in the last seven years her retail business has been operating in Nakazadde, Lugazi, she has had to adhere to the one factor that is a winning stock in any trade -hard work. She wanted to vie with her friends who were successful in their business ventures. Her personal savings from her restaurant business came in handy in helping her get her business off its feet. Weekly, her business generates 420,000 shillings. This is testimony as to how profitable this business is. She is requesting this loan to buy more merchandise for her shop. She is looking at buying more bags of maize flour (a favorite in her operating area), bags of sugar, salt and plastics.

loans.use: To buy maize flour, sugar, salt and plastics.

loans.name: Marifat's Group

texts.en: Marifat S. is the leader of this group. She is 46 and married with has two sons: the first son is married and works in the power station and the second son has just graduated from school. Marifat sells flour in the market and her husband sells meat. They have been doing this activity for eighteen years and in this way they make 20,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan Marifat wants to start repairing her house. In the future she plans to purchase a piece of land and start building a store. Alimbek M., 36, is married and has a newborn daughter. He is engaged in livestock and his wife works in a barber shop. He also sells fruits and vegetables on the market and in this way he earns 7,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase farm animals for breeding. In the future he plans to purchase a vehicle to work as a taxi driver when he is free. Jyldyz S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 28 and divorced with two daughters: the first daughter is at school and the second is not yet attending. Ten years ago, with an initial investment of 10,000 soms, Jyldyz bought a calf and three goats for breeding. She also takes orders for sewing the national cloth and for dressmaking supplies and in this way she makes 3,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase five goats to increase the number of her livestock. In the future she plans to purchase a container and start her own business. Ulanbek S. is 22 and married with a newborn daughter. He has been engaged in livestock since childhood and applied for the loan because he wants to purchase three sheep to increase the number of his livestock. In the near future he wants to celebrate his wedding. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To start repairing her house

loans.name: Oman Ni-Eye

texts.fr: B. exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pagnes. elle a une ancienneté de 2 ans dans ce commerce. elle fait son activité de façon ambulante. sa clientèle ne cesse de grandir. elle veut accroître son stock pour servir un plus grand nombre de clients c'est pour cela qu'elle demande à waqes un crédit pour l'achat d'une dizaine de pagnes de qualité  HI-TARGET et une dizaine de pagnes de qualité GTP.
texts.en:
Mrs. B. has been selling pagnes (a colorful West African cloth) for two years. She sells these pagnes as an itinerant vendor and her client base continues to grow. She wants to increase her stock in order to serve a greater number of customers. She is requesting a loan through WAGES so she can purchase ten Hi-Target pagnes and ten GTP pagnes.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase pagnes

loans.name: Buntuuse Farmers Assocation, Lugazi Group

texts.en:
Success in any business is not necessarily measured by what an individual has achieved but by the obstacles that the individual has overcome along the way as he or she transacts. 27-year-old K. John has had a checkered track record that he says makes him carry conviction that the above is true.

In the four years John has been plying his retail shop business, he has come to terms with the fact that when one experiences firsthand the hardships associated with running a business, it becomes a defining moment in the success or failure of that venture.

The married father of one has brought personal values to his business with determination and perseverance. Weekly, his business generates him 40,000 shillings and, because the cost of living in Busaale, Lugazi, is not that high, John can successfully make ends meet.

With the auspices of this loan, John wants to buy more bags of sugar, bags of rice, and bars of soap for his retail shop. He is planning on selling them to earn more profits.

loans.use: To purchase of more bags of sugar, bags of rice, and bars of soap to sell

loans.name: Muhamed

texts.en:
N. Muhamed, at 53, still works vigorously hard to be able to earn enough to make ends meet out of profits from his one-year-old retail shop in Kitimba, Mpigi. He mostly sells home utensils like basins, plates and cutlery. In a month, he can make as much as 100,000 shillings.

Muhamed has eight kids, all going to school. He has to shoulder all the responsibilities of educating his children and providing meals and medication for them. To do all this he knows he has to summon up all the diligence he has in him.

Customers have been coming steadily and Muhamed is anticipating a scenario where he will attract even more with additional purchases of goods that are in high favor with his community members. He set forth with savings from a produce-selling business. Though it still exists, it is now low key but enables him to get food mostly for home consumption.

Muhamed is requesting this loan to purchase more retail items such as sugar, groundnuts (peanuts), beans, rice and maize flour to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items such as sugar, groundnuts, beans and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Jibarbu

texts.en: Jibarbu I. is a resident of Tashkomur, a small town in the Jalalabad region. She is 55 and a widow with two children: the older one is at school and the second is not yet attending. Seventeen years ago, with an initial investment of 20,000 soms, Jibarbu began to sell goods at the local market. Then she invested money to start building a big store. Now, half of the building she leases out, and the second half she uses to sell her own goods. She sells a variety of goods, such as clothes, shoes, curtains and dishes. With the money received from the loan Jibarbu wants to purchase different styles of carpet, school uniforms, and other clothes to sell everything that in her store. In the future she wants to expand her business and start reconstruction of her store. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase school uniforms and different styles of carpet

loans.name: Bunawona Women's Group 1, Kayunga

texts.en:
45-year-old N. Elzabeth values highly her hard-work-oriented attitude and it’s for this reason she affirms her business has managed to endure for the last ten years. She operates her food-selling business in Kyabazala market, Kayunga. She began this business on her own and that is one fact she is exhilarated about.

Elzabeth’s easygoing and happy-go-lucky line of conduct has played so much in her favor. Striking that good first impression with clients is always a winning trump card in any business. This mother of two makes 30,000 shillings weekly and with this she has been able to keep her head above water.

Elzabeth is asking for this loan to be able to buy more maize flour, cow peas and cooking oil to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more maize flour, cow peas and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Nadhra

texts.en:
Nadhra is a married woman with two boys, 14 and 10 years old, who both attend school. Her husband is employed and he contributes to the family’s basic needs. Nadhra owns a house with electricity but no piped water. Her major monthly expenses are food, electricity, clothing and school fees.

Nadhra has been operating her business of selling soft drinks for the last five years. She sells by going from door to door and also sells from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of competition in her business.

With the Kshs 30,000, she wants to start another business of buying handbags and shoes wholesale and selling them retail. Her major goal is to own her own shop in future.

Nadhra decided to work with Yehu so as to access loans to improve her living standard.

loans.use: To purchase handbags and shoes to sell

loans.name: Purity Wanjohi

texts.en:
Purity is a 34-year-old married lady with two children. She sells buckets, mattresses, and handbags in an open-air market. She has been in the business for about four years now and has managed to get a profit of about Kshs.26,000 per month.

She has never borrowed from any other MFI. She hopes to open her own shop and improve her living standards.

loans.use: To buy more buckets, other utensils, mattresses, and bags for resale

loans.name: Bunawona Group 2, Kayunga

texts.en:
To have any sort of future success in her retail shop business, 28-year-old K. Susan knows it’s incumbent upon her to keep planning and to constantly restock. That is a magic formula to success, especially with retail enterprises.

Susan says she read the parable about talents in the bible that says most people lack the confidence to do something because they are afraid of failure. She says she chose to make an exception to that parable, well knowing she had confidence and that courage of conviction succeeds in any undertaking.

Susan is a good-natured married woman with three kids who all attend school in Bunawona. Her customers cut across all levels but it’s mostly the lowest common denominators who are her patrons. In a week her profits add up to 180,000 shillings. She also gets some profits from a poultry business.

With this loan Susan wants purchase goodies like salt, bars of soap and maize flour to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more salt, bags of soap and maize flour for her shop

loans.name: Wazaria

texts.fr: en 2002 B. a débuté le commerce de produits d'alimention générale. elle exerce son commerce dans le marché local d'atsanvé à Lomé. elle s'approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé. Son stock actuel de marchandises est en baisse. elle voudrait s'approvisionner et demande un premier crédit à WAGES afin de s'acheter 10 sacs de riz, 5 sacs d'haricots, 5 bidons d'huile, 7 cartons de sucre et  divers.
texts.en:
In 2002, Ms. B. began selling general food items. She sells her goods at the Atsanvé local market in Lomé. She purchases her stock at the Lomé Grand Market. Her current stock of items is low. She would like to increase her stock and is requesting her first loan through WAGES so she can purchase 10 sacks of rice, 5 sacks of beans, 5 jugs of oil, 7 boxes of sugar, and other items.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food items

loans.name: Cissy

texts.en:
Cissy K. lives in the Ndeeba neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members. She lives in a home that she rents and has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, rent and school fees.

Cissy has a retail shop business and has been in this business for five years, working every day. She has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar, boxes of soap, cartons of salt and jerrycans of cooking oil.

The main business challenges for Cissy include transportation and the rainy season. Her goals and aspirations for her business and family are to see her business grow big, to start selling wholesale and to educate her children up to university level.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and jerrycans of cooking oil for her shop

loans.name: Janigul

texts.en: Janigul E. K. is a resident of Kadamjai, a nice town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 20 and married with a newborn daughter. Janigul is engaged in the retail trade of women’s shoes and her husband works as a taxi driver. Janigul started her business three years ago with an initial investment of 20,000 soms and now she earns 7,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to purchase a vehicle for her husband. Janigul applied for this loan because she wants to expand her business and purchase a variety of shoes. In the future she plans to start building her own store. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Busaana Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
47-year-old M. Alex is a self-assured and high-spirited married father of seven kids, four of whom attend school.

It’s now stretching to a decade since Alex began his fish-selling business in Busaana, Lugazi. He describes himself as a hard-worker with a purpose. He was previously getting his livelihood from a farming business.

Alex supplements his weekly profits of 150,000 shillings with additional money from his commercial motorcycle business.

Under the auspices of this loan, Alex wants to renovate his boats and also buy new fishing nets. His future plan is to own over ten boats.

Alex says that since he joined Pearl Microfinance for loans, he has benefited by completing the construction of his family house.

loans.use: To renovate his boats and also to purchase new fishing nets

loans.name: Kiira Womens Group-Lugazi

texts.en: A framework of basic ideas related to how best to run a business has helped 36-year-old N. Lukia steadily and painstakingly find her stride in her second-hand clothes business in Buloba-Lugazi. It’s now five years since she began with savings from her framing business. Without a shadow of a doubt, she is basking in the glow of her hard work. Her monthly business profits add up to 200,000 shillings. For this married mother of six, this success does not mean that she is resting on her laurels. Instead she is looking at expansion. She is requesting this loan to be able to buy more bales of second-hand clothing to resell.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is a 28-year-old married lady.  She is blessed with two children: Kevin Mwangi, 12, and Cindy Waithera, 4, who are both in school.  

She operates Wamwesh Salon in an-open air market called Kawangware Market.  She has two employees whom she pays on commission.  She has been engaged in the business for seven years.  She was previously selling second-hand clothes.  

She is happy with the current business because she does it as a hobby and she earns better income. She hopes to expand her business and open a cosmetic shop in the future.    

Salome joined Umoja B group under Faulu Kenya three years ago.  Through the group, she is requesting 40,000 KES to rent a spacious business premises and to add to her stock of hair braids, weaves and shampoo.

loans.use: To rent a spacious business premise and add hair braids, weaves and shampoo.

loans.name: Nigina

texts.ru: Рахимова Нигина проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 42 года. Вдова, имеет 2 детей. Старшая дочь работает учительницей в школе. Сама Нигина предоставляет услугу. Берет заказы на дому, она в основном шьет национальные платья. В этой области имеет богатый опыт. Более 15 лет занимается шитьем. Целью кредита является закуп швейной машинки
texts.en:
Nigina R. lives in Tursun-zoda. 42 years old, she is a widow with two children. The eldest daughter works as a school teacher. Nigina provides sewing services, working on client’s orders out of her home. She mainly sews traditional Tadjik outfits. She has a lot of experience in this field as she has been doing it for over 15 years. The purpose of this loan is purchasing a sewing machine.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing a sewing machine

loans.name: Eldiyar

texts.en:
Eldiyar K. is a 28-year-old farmer who lives in Bekitay village. He is married and has one little daughter. Eldiyar was born into a large family where all the children helped their parents in farming. He was the oldest one so he had to do all of the hard work around the house. He pastured cattle, plowed the land and gathered in the harvest. 

At that time, Eldiyar’s family had one cow and one bull-calf. Later on, they got more cattle. In 2008, Eldiyar got married. His parents gave him one horse and one milk cow, which became the first investment in Eldiyar’s own business. 

During the last two years, his efforts have been aimed at supporting and expanding his household. He managed to multiply the number of cattle and today he has five milk cows and fifteen sheep. Also, he cultivated vegetables on a plot of land and worked hard to get a good harvest of high quality products. 

Eldiyar applied for a loan of 50,000 KGS to buy five bull-calves. With the revenues from this investment, he plans to broaden his business by purchasing more cattle for fattening. Speaking of his plans for future, Eldiyar dreams of establishing a large farm and building his own house. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading micro-finance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of micro-finance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 31-year-old single lady.  She has a 10-year-old child.  She owns and operates Wambu Salon to earn a living.  She has been in the business for five years and has three employees.  

She is a member of Kikambura East group in Faulu Kenya.  She also saves her money with the group.  With support from the group, she previously serviced two loans from Faulu Kenya.  She has requested a new loan of 80,000 KES to buy a massage bed, foot spa and cosmetics. She describes herself as patient, humble and God-fearing.

loans.use: To purchase a massage bed, foot spa and cosmetics

loans.name: Inocencia

texts.en:
Inocencia S. is a widow who lives in Barangay Tiniguiban, Puerto Princesa, Palawan. She earns her living by operating four business ventures: a restaurant, a general store, a farm and a room-for-rent business. 

Inocencia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Inocencia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of 35,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of $675, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 16th cycle loan, she is borrowing 40,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase ingredients for the food she sells in her restaurant and to start a new business selling soft drinks wholesale. 

She works hard and wants to expand her business so that she can continue to save up for future home repairs. Inocencia S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for the food she sells and capital for new wholesale soft drinks business

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a single lady with one child. She operates Natures Secrets salon. She has been engaged in the business for ten years. She is a member of Shirley's group in Faulu Kenya where she accesses loans through group guarantee. She also saves her money on a weekly basis with the group.  

She has requested a loan of 40,000 KES to add to her stock of beauty products. She hopes to have a well established business and introduce new products. Josephine says that she is a hardworking lady.

loans.use: To add to her stock of beauty products

loans.name: Aibek

texts.en:
Aibek M. is a resident of Kadamjai, a nice town in southern Kyrgyzstan.  He is 26 years old and married. Ten years ago, with the initial investment of 1,000 KGS, he started to breed cattle. Selling some cattle after fattening, he makes 5,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for him to save money and celebrate his wedding.  

With money received from the loan Aibek wants to purchase six farm animals to resell them after fattening. In the future he plans to increase the number of cattle and start building a new house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only micro-finance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase six farm animals

loans.name: Samihatou

texts.fr: A. exerce depuis plus de 10 ans déjà le commerce de charbons de bois. elle vend le charbons de bois à domicile et sert tout son quartier. elle s'approvisionne à l'intérieur du pays dans la localité de WAHALA. elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de sacs de charbons de bois afin de rehausser son stock et assurer le transport de la marchandises
texts.en:
Ms. A. has already run her business selling charcoal for more than 10 years. She sells charcoal from her home and serves everyone in her neighborhood. She stocks up in the interior of the country in the locality of Wahala. She is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy bags of charcoal in order to enhance her supply and to ensure the transport of her merchandise.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Nemat

texts.en:
Nemat is a small producer in the city of Istaravshan in Tajikistan. Together with his children they’ve been raising cattle for more than five years. These produce the income which allows him to feed his family. As well as caring for his livestock, he also cultivates an agricultural crop, wheat, which helps with the family's diet and provides additional income. 

Nemat has asked for this loan to buy young cattle in order to obtain a better profit. His greatest wish is to be able to improve his farm by constructing enclosures and establishing better grazing for his livestock.  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase young cattle and construction materials for improving his cattle shed

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah is married to a peasant farmer and they have six children, four of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members, her grandchildren. 

She owns a stall at her home in Nakulabye, where she sells fish purchased at the Gaba landing site.  Deborah goes shopping twice a week and uses public transport to and from Gaba. 

She wants to use this loan to buy more baskets of fish.  She sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. She has been with MCDT for many years, now servicing her 12th loan. She works seven days a week. Her business aspiration is to start selling wholesale only.   

She decided to work with MCDT because of the low interest charged and their good customer care. Deborah resides in and owns a house where the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: to buy more baskets of fish to sell

loans.name: Mahamadou Rahama

texts.fr: Mahamadou Rahama est une femme mariée et mère de 3 enfants, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de bois de chauffage, elle a une ancienneté de 5 ans dans ce commerce. Elle s'approvisionne au nord du pays dans la localité de WAHALA.le stock dont elle dispose actuellement ne lui permet pas de satisfaire toute sa clientèle. elle sollicite donc de WAGES un premier crédit pour s'approvisionner avec une quarantaine de sacs de charbons de bois et assurer le transport de la marchandise.
texts.en:
Mrs. S. is married and the mother of 3 children. She runs a money-making business selling heating wood. She has 5 years of experience in the business. She stocks up in the north of the country in the locality of Wahala. The stock which she currently has at her disposal does not allow her to meet the needs of her customers. She is therefore requesting her first loan from WAGES in order to stock up with some forty bags of heating wood and to ensure the transport of her merchandise.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy heating wood

loans.name: Kuvvanjbek

texts.en:
Selling construction supplies at the market has become the only source of income for Kuvvanjbek, a 23-year-old man who's been doing this for three years. This young man has many projects for his future, and to build his own house and family is one of them. He's good at what he does, and this is why he's been able to support himself and his whole family through his business. 

His wish is to add more goods and in that way increase the range of materials and supplies to offer to his clients. Kuvvanjbek would pay back this loan and with the money earned he would be able to pay for his technical career education.

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing pipe, angle bar, and other construction materials

loans.name: Adjara

texts.fr: cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de vêtements pour enfant. elle les achète au grand marché de lomé et les revend à ses clients avec une légère marge bénéficiaire. elle fait son commerce de façon ambulante. elle voudrait s'approvisionner et sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de quelques habits pour enfants constitués de trousseaux de bébé, T-shirt, jupe,culotte, chaussette, pantalon. elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants.
texts.en:
This woman runs a money-making business selling children's clothing. She buys them at the big market of Lomé and resells them to her clients at a small profit margin. She runs a travelling business. She would like to stock up on supplies and is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy some children's outfits including baby clothes, T-shirts, skirts, underwear, socks and pants. She is married and the mother of 3 children.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy children's clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more drugs and beds for admitting patients

loans.name: Taibatou

texts.fr: T. exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits d'alimentation générale, elle fait ce commerce depuis très longtemps déjà. elle y a associé une activité saisonnière qui se trouve être le commerce d'articles scolaires. la rentrée scolaire étant proches elle souhaiterait s'approvisionner en articles scolaires et profiter acheter quelques produits d'alimentation générale raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de wages un prêt pour acheter  2 cartons de cahiers,  1 cartons de bics, 1 cartons de crayons et divers autres produits d'alimentation générale. elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. T. runs a money-making business selling general food products. She has already run her shop for a very long time. Along with this business, she runs a seasonal business selling educational items. With the beginning of the school year approaching, she wishes to stock up on educational items and and to buy some general food products, which is why she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 2 boxes of notebooks, 1 box of Bic pens, 1 box of pencils and various other general food products. She is married and the mother of 3 children.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy general food products

loans.name: Mamatou

texts.fr: ouro afrignan est une femme mariée et mère de 4 enfants, elle s'est lancée en 1999 dans le commerce de pagnes auquel il a associé la vente de bijoux. elle s'approvisionne en pagnes au grand marché de Lomé et en bijoux à cotonou. elle n'a pas de difficultés à faire écouler sa marchandise. la demande actuelle de sa clientèle est élevée. elle doit s'approvisionner pour les satisfaire, elle sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour acheter  25 pagnes de différentes qualités et des bijoux.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ouro Afrignan is married and the mother of 4 children. She got involved in selling fabrics, and eventually included the sale of jewelry. She stocks up on fabrics at the big market in Lomé and on jewelry in Cotonou. She has had no problem exhausting her stock of merchandise. Her clients' current demands have gotten higher. She must stock up in order to satisfy their needs, so she is requesting her first loan from WAGES in order to buy 25 different quality fabrics and jewelry.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics and jewelry

loans.name: Khairullo

texts.en: Khairullo is 36 years old and he makes a living buying and selling livestock. He's married with three children who he must feed and educate. Over the years, he has become very knowledgeable about what is required to raise cattle, their feeding, their calving, etc. It should be noted that, in the past, this man endured hard economic times for a while, but he's managed to come through thanks to the help provided by IMON International. IMON International has granted him loans that he has used to buy calves, which is the reason that he needs this loan now. The loan will greatly improve Khairullo’s income and his family's living standard. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase more calves

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy and sell fresh fish

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en:
Kennedy is a married man who uses his motorbike for transport to earn a living.

Kennedy was introduced to Fumulia group in Faulu Kenya and, through the group, he has been able to save his money. He was previously guaranteed two loans which he used to boost his business.

Kennedy has requested a loan of 90,000 KES which he will use to buy a motorbike. He hopes to add more motorbikes for transport so as to earn a better income.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Shoirjon

texts.en: I. Shoirjon is a young man who has dedicated himself to the livestock industry from his childhood. He has been characterized as a very spirited and strong person whose successes are directly applied to his young family, composed of his wife and three children. The work Shoirjon does is through the raising of livestock for eventual sale. It is necessary to point out that this is the only income that supports his family and that they really need it. Today, Shoirjon looks for support from IMON International to obtain the necessary loan to purchase more cows to raise. With this loan, his beloved family will benefit as much as he will. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase more calves to raise and sell

loans.name: Abdumanon

texts.en: K. Abdumanon is a diligent and tenacious farmer who strives to meet his family’s needs. He is widower, and thus he carries the burden alone through his farming income to meet his family’s needs. Abdumanon works on a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) farm owned by his parents. His harvests are sometimes not maximized because his cultivation method and seeds are not the best. Better farming supplies, seeds and fertilizer require a larger capital, which he didn’t have. Abdumanon is now relieved that IMON International is helping him obtain the loan he needs to improve his farming. This loan will be used to buy superior seeds, organic fertilizers, and pesticides. He is waiting for his next harvest, which he hopes will yield better results than his previous harvests. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.use: To purchase superior seeds, organic fertilizers, and pesticides

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 22-year-old single man from Tripoli, Lebanon. He has owned a barber shop since 2006 and has eight years of experience.

This is Mohamad’s first time requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to do some useful decorations to his shop. In addition, he will change all the shop’s furniture to attract new clients and retain old clients’ attention. He plans to buy a new couch, tables, hairdryers, a haircutting machine, a wax machine, catalogues and paint the walls.

Mohamad likes his work a lot. He believes that a person must work hard on improving his workspace in order to succeed and insure business continuity.

loans.use: To make some useful decorations to his shop in addition to replacing all the shop’s furniture

loans.name: Liver Pool Group

texts.en:
These entrepreneurs named their group “Liverpool”, after their favourite football team. They are small-scale businesswomen in Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 800,000 for each to enable them to expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 800,000, they will be able to add more stock to their businesses, make more sales, and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by sending their children to school, feeding and clothing them. 

Fatmata K. K. is the leader of this group. She was born in Magburaka town thirty-two years ago. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a medical practitioner; two of her children are attending primary school and one in secondary school.  

Fatmata sells dishes, clothes, and shoes. She has been running this business for two years now. With her share of this loan she will buy dishes, clothes and shoes wholesale to add to her business inventory. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo).

loans.use: Buy dishes, clothes and shoes for resale

loans.name: Kamuyu Association Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Kamuyu Association” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,200,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Aminata L. who is pictured on the left. The thirty-year-old Aminata was born in Magburaka, is married, and has five children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending school – two in secondary school, two in primary school and one is still an infant. 

Aminata owns a stall at the Magburaka town market wherein she sells peppers, sugar, Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), etc. She has been a businesswoman for many years now. With the help of this loan, she will expand her business by buying in large quantity the above-mentioned goods.

loans.use: Buy peppers, sugar, etc. wholesale

loans.name: Sam Maraneh Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “Sam Maraneh” group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the township of Magburaka, in Northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of SLL 800,000 for each from SMT/Kiva lenders.  With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, making more sales and better profit. 

Fatmata K. is the leader of this group. Fatmata was born in Magburaka. She is forty-one years of age, married, with two children who are attending secondary school. Fatmata has been in business for many years now; she sells drinks and clothes. She will use this loan to buy more drinks and clothes to add to her business. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy more drinks and clothes to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 22-year-old man living in Chtaura, Lebanon. Ahmad has been working as a freelance electrician since 2003, 7 years of experience. Ahmad is professional in his work as most of his neighbors claim. This is Ahmad’s first time to request a loan from Al Majmoua, in order to buy the necessary equipment for his work, which helps in improving his output since he can do more things in less time. 

Ahmad hopes that through this loan his output will become better and his income will rise which will help him cover his engagement costs. Ahmad hopes to become a well-known electric contractor everyone turns to.

loans.use: To buy the necessary equipment for his work

loans.name: Zarifjon

texts.en:
M. Zarifjon lives in Istaravshan, Tajikistan, where he is a successful businessman who has been selling a variety of spare parts for foreign cars over the past 16 years. The father of three children, he provides the family with necessary food and other needs. 

Zarifjon is a great example of someone who started out with a few products that hardly anyone would buy. Currently Zarifjon is requesting a loan of 3000 USD with which to re-stock his inventory and purchase more merchandise. This loan will increase his business sales, allowing Zarifjon to diversify his merchandise and better provide for his family.

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts for cars for resale

loans.name: Action Group Ii

texts.en:
Meet members of “Action group II" from Magburaka, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Kadiatu K. is the leader of this group. The twenty-five-year-old is married to a businessman and they have two children who are attending primary school. Kadiatu has been a businesswoman for five years now. She sells palm oil (the country’s favorite cooking oil) and rice. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items wholesale to add to her business inventory. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy palm oil and rice

loans.name: Maberah Group

texts.en:
Meet members of the “Maberah” group, petty businesspeople in the township of Magburaka, in Northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 400,000 for each to enable them expand their businesses. 

The leader of this group is Idrissa F.. Forty-one-year-old Idrissa was born in Maberah village, is married to a businessman, and they have five children – three in primary school and two in secondary school. 

Idrissa sells fish, rice, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil) and groundnuts/peanuts. She will use her share of the loan to buy rice, palm oil, and groundnuts in large quantity to add to her business. 

(Attached to this photo are some snapshots of borrowers who were not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy fish, rice, palm oil and groundnuts

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida N. is 48 years old and lives in the town of Lukaya in the Masaka region of Uganda.  She is single and has 2 children.  Neither of her children is currently in school.  Aida has a business of outside catering, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Aida has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more dishes, plates, serving spoons, and warmers.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Aida hopes to generate greater profits.  In the future, Aida hopes to take her business to a strategic place where she can get more customers.

loans.use: to buy more plates, spoons, serving dishes, and warmers

loans.name: Abduhamid

texts.en:
M. Abduhamid is 25 years old. He is married and has a little daughter. His wife is a teacher at secondary school. Abduhamid is producing tinware. He has been in this business already for 5 years. The finished products are purchased from the house of Abduhamid. The business stability allows him to have income and to ensure the family has the possibility to improve their living conditions. Today Abduhamid  is requesting a loan in the amount of 1500 US Dollars in order to purchase raw materials for producing tinware.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of raw material for making tinware

loans.name: Inomdjon

texts.en:
M. Inomdjon is 58 years old. He is married with three children. Inomdjon has been in business baking bread for the last 12 years. Inomdjon is the main bread-winner in the family and his sons help him with the business. The input materials are as rule purchased by Inomdjon in the local market.

Over the years of his business, Inomdjon found wholesale customers; those usually buy “lepeshka” for their cafes and restaurants. Today Inomdjon is applying for a loan for the third time. He is planning to purchase input materials like flour and coal for baking the bread. With this purpose he requests 1150 US Dollars. Inomdjon would like to thank everyone supporting him and promises to repay the loan in a timely manner. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing flour and coal required for baking bread

loans.name: Gracemary

texts.en:
This is 51-year-old Gracemary.  She is married and has 3 children; one is working and the other 2 are in school. She has 3 additional dependents, who live with her, because she wants them to assist her and to attend school.  In 2007, Gracemary established her pharmaceutical drugs business. She began her business because she needed to help her husband to provide basic needs for the family. She works 7 days a week and 12 hours a day. She earns about 1,723,200 SLL every month from this business. 

Gracemary would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL. She requires a loan in order to expand from a drug store to a full-time pharmacy. She hopes to help her grandchildren through school. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 516,960 SLL. 

In the future, Gracemary plans to become a qualified nurse to make her different from other proprietors of pharmaceutical drug businesses.  She believes a brighter future is in store for her and her business. The majority of her patients are little children from poor backgrounds. She plans to tear down the old store and open a new bigger one.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more medicine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more duplicating paper and toner

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes L. is 42 years old and lives in the town of Lukaya in the Masaka region of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children. Agnes has a business that deals with all types of drinks, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Agnes has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more drinks, especially mineral water.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Agnes hopes to generate greater profits and to educate her children.  In the future, Agnes hopes to further expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more drinks like beers, mineral water, and soda

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A.  is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs in a restaurant  and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs in the restaurant.  Mary is 39 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase more chairs and tables to be used in the restaurant.

loans.use: Stock more foodstuffs for her little restaurant

loans.name: Tobias

texts.en: Tobias is a 30-year-old married man.  He has been making charts, boards, and catalogues for three years. He mainly sells charts to schools. Before he went into the business, he was operating a stationery shop.   He also runs a barber shop to earn extra income.   He has been a member of New Jerusalem group under Faulu Kenya.  He has been able to service two loans which he used to boost the business.  He has been granted a loan of 80,000 KES to buy a scroll saw and a sanding machine.  He hopes to expand his business so as to raise his living standards.

loans.use: To buy a scroll saw and sanding machine

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
This is 42-year-old Isatu.  She is married and has 2 children, aged 18 and 16. She has 7 additional dependents, some of whom are school-going children.  In 2002, Isatu established pure water, soft drinks, and ladies' and men's wear businesses. She began her business because she was sure that by doing so she could be helpful in solving domestic problems and also establish strong customer relations for possible expansion of her business. 

 Working 6 days a week and 9 hours a day, Isatu earns about Le 1,685,400 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL.   She requires a loan in order to expand her business by buying additional stock.  She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 252,810 SLL.  

In the future, Isatu plans to sells goods that always match the season.  Isatu moves around a lot in order to sell her goods.  She sells to all categories of people but the majority are youth.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a member of 'Mwiki Dreamers' in Faulu Kenya.  Through the group, she has managed to operate her butcher shop well and has employed three people.  She has been running the business for three years. She previously took out a loan of 30,000 KES to boost the business.  

Susan is also engaged in construction business.  Besides that, she earns extra income from the pool table which she rents out.  She has requested 65,000 KES to buy cows for slaughter.  She hopes to operate several outlets in the future.  She describes herself as a hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy cows for slaughter

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en:
This is 37-year-old Ramatu.  She is married and has 3 children aged 19, 17, and 12. She has 2 additional dependents, who live with her because one of them lost his mother and the other is her husband's younger brother.  

In 2003, Ramatu established her ice cream and yogurt ice business. She began her business because her husband’s income is low so she started business to meet the home challenges. Her business has gone from one freezer to now eight. Working 6 days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about 3,440,000 SLL every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000. 

Ramatu requires a loan in order to increase her purchases of raw materials. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 344,000 SLL. In the future, Ramatu plans to send her two children to university and to increase production.   Competition is there but the quality of her production helps her business.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more raw materials

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is a married man with five children who are in school.  He is employed in a security firm in Nairobi.  Besides that, he runs a retail shop where he has employed one person.  He was previously working as a plumber to earn a living. He has been running his retail shop for six months, thanks to Faulu Kenya for training him in business management.  

Currently, Richard needs to add vegetables, sugar, maize flour and cooking fat  to his inventory so as to meet his customers’ needs.  Hence, he has requested a loan of 60,000 KES. He hopes to open a manufacturing industry and create employment.

loans.use: To add vegetables, sugar, maize flour and cooking fat to his business inventory

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is 35 years old.  She is married, and has 2 children, aged 14 and 11 years. In 2002, Zainab established her foodstuffs business. She began her business because after high school, she preferred going into business with a very small start.   She now appreciates the level of stock and the huge customer base she has. Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about 1,767,600 SLL every month from this business. 

Zainab would like a loan in the amount of 4,000,000 SLL. Zainab requires a loan in order to purchase stock wholesale. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 123,732 SLL. For the future, Zainab is confident and full of hope as she is the sole trader, doing business in a new community. She hopes to build a whole store and to send her children to university.  The majority of the people in her community are poor women, men and children. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is a 45-year-old married woman. She does construction work to earn a living and runs a retail shop to earn extra income. She has engaged in the business for 10 years. She became a member of Kasa group in Faulu Kenya so as to access loans. She has managed to take out three loans from Faulu Kenya. Because she has a good reputation for paying back her loans, she has been guaranteed another loan of 70,000 KES. She will use the loan to buy building materials like cement and sand. She dreams of owning real estate in the future. she describes herself as determined and motivated.

loans.use: To buy cement and sand

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
Juan vive en vivienda propia con su esposa e hijos en la zona de Pasankeri, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, esta casado tiene cuatro hijos que están en edad escolar, el señor realiza trabajos de construcción en viviendas particulares de esta ciudad, con los ingresos que obtiene mantiene a su familia; la esposa realiza tejidos artesanales para una tienda de exportación. El crédito que saco anteriormente fue para el revoque y pintado de una habitación que es el único dormitorio con el que cuentan, es cliente de Impro con 5 créditos. El señor se encuentra satisfecho con los créditos que le otorgamos. El crédito que ahora solicita es para la compra de 1000 ladrillos para la construcción de una habitación más en su casa.

Por su antecedente histórico califica para obtener un nuevo crédito. Se considera a Juan como buen cliente.
texts.en:
Juan lives in his own home together with his wife and children in the Pasankeri community in the city of La Paz. He is married and he has four school aged children. He is a private contractor in the city. The income that he earns supports his family. His wife knits crafts that are sold to an export company. The loan that was previously disbursed to him was used to renovate and repaint the only bedroom in their house. He has been a member of Impro (Kiva Field Partner) and has had 5 previous loans. He is very grateful for the loans he has received. The loan he requests is to purchase 1000 bricks to build another bedroom in their house. His previous history grants him access to another loan. Juan has been a good client.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 1000 bricks to make home improvements.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is a 44-year-old married lady. Her husband is a mechanic, while she supplies milk products. She has been in the business for 10 years. She gets the milk products from KCC Ltd (a well-known milk processing plant). She joined Bumbani group as a businesswoman so as to save money. She is able to access loans from Faulu Kenya, because the group members guarantee each others loans. She needs capital for buying milk products for resale.  Therefore, she has requested for a loan of 60,000 KES. In 10 years, she wants to open other business outlets.

loans.use: To buy milk products for resale

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.es:
Rogelio vive en vivienda propia con su esposa e hijos en la zona de Llojeta, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz; está casado y tiene dos hijos que están en edad escolar.

 Rogelio realiza trabajos de joyería para la venta a joyerías de la ciudad, con los ingresos que obtiene mantiene a su familia, la esposa le ayuda en ese trabajo; el crédito que saco anteriormente fue para la construcción de un muro posterior, ya que su vivienda se encontraba expuesta a posibles asaltos y robos. Es cliente de Impro con 5 créditos, todos cancelados. El crédito que ahora solicita es para iniciar la construcción de dos habitaciones para tener mayor comodidad. El señor se encuentra satisfecho con los créditos que le otorgamos.

Por su antecedente histórico califica para obtener un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Rogelio lives in his own house together with his wife and children in the Llojeta community in the city of La Paz. He is married and he has two school aged children. Rogelio makes jewelry for private sales and for sale to jewelry stores. With his earnings he supports his family. His wife also works in making jewelry. The previous loan was used to build a back wall to their house. The room was previously exposed and they ran the risk of being attacked or robbed. He has been a member of Impro (Kiva Field Partner) and he has had 5 previous loans, all of which have been repaid. The loan he requests is to start the construction of two other bedrooms in their house, to provide greater comfort to their family. He is very grateful for the loan he is granted. His previous history grants him access to another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make home improvements.

loans.name: Ddembe Women's Group-Lugazi

texts.en: Fifty-four-year-old Robinah N. always takes stock of her business dealings at the end of every operating day. This, the married mother of six says, has helped her give a good account of not only her business, but herself, too. Five years of operating a food sales business at a stall in Buikwe market-Lugazi has kept her well grounded. Prior to running this business, she was a housewife. Much encouragement from a friend helped her take root. In a week, she makes profits that total up to 320,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to purchase more maize flour, rice, cassava, potatoes and beans for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more food for resale

loans.name: Nazighe

texts.en: Nazighe is a 52-year-old married woman with four children. She runs Zena Salon to earn a living. She has been in the business for 10 years, but was previously selling vegetables. She joined Keen Ventures group in Faulu Kenya with the aim of getting financial support. So far, she has managed to get one loan from Faulu Kenya. She is requesting for 40,000 KES to add to her stock of beauty products. She plans to grow her business so as to serve more customers. She dreams of owning a beauty college in the future.

loans.use: To add to her stock of beauty products

loans.name: Geraida

texts.en: Geraida is widowed with four children, none of whom goes to school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. She owns a stall at her home in Mengo Mackay, selling rice. She wants to use this loan of 800,000 UGX to buy more bags of rice. She has been in this rice business for many years. She buys bags of rice from Kamuli district and uses public transport to and from Kamuli. Besides the rice business, she also gets additional income from rental rooms. She sells to all categories of people for retail and works six days a week. She depends on this job for a living, and her main business challenge is the transportation of bags of rice from Kamuli to her home in Mengo Mackay. She aspires to own a delivery van and also to start selling on wholesale only. She decided to join MCDT because they are cooperative and work with poor women. Geraida resides in and owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes food and paying utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice

loans.name: Policarpo

texts.es:
Para Policarpo P. V. su actividad como docente nunca termina, porque aunque es pensionado del Magisterio, aun sigue ejerciendo su vocación de maestro, pero ahora cuando asesora a sus clientes en todo lo relacionado con la nutrición;  y  es que el profesor Policarpo a sus  61 años, se dedica a la comercialización de productos nutricionales, para aumentar  las defensas del organismo, dinamizarlo y equilibrarlo, pero también vende variedades, como ropa, calzado y electrodomésticos menores. Su negocio lo inició en el año 2005, cuando era docente en el Departamento de Bolívar, pero una vez pensionado empezó a comercializar de una manera más persistente, porque siempre está dispuesto a trabajar para cada día generar más ingresos. Su mercado lo constituyen muchos amigos del gremio educativo, familiares, recomendados, pero especialmente empleados que tengan buenos hábitos de pago. Este su credikiva, es  su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo,  con él comprará   productos nutricionales  al por mayor y de contado, además de mercancía para la temporada como electrodomésticos menores y sobre todo ropa y calzado, aprovechando la alta demanda en el segundo semestre del año, por parte de sus mercados.
 
Su meta es continuar incrementando las ventas para mejorar su nivel de vida y lo más importante es que a Policarpo le favorece mucho su ubicación pues está en el epicentro del comercio del sur de Barranquilla, cerca al estadio Metropolitano de esta ciudad, escenario cuna del futbol Colombiano.
texts.en:
For Policarpo P. V., his work as a teacher never ends. Even though he's retired from teaching, he continues practicing his vocation, but now he advises his students on everything relating to nutrition. At 61 years old, Professor Policarpo works marketing nutritional products to improve the body's defenses while energizing and balancing it. He also sells a variety of additional products, like clothes, shoes, and small electrical appliances. He began his business in 2005 when he was a teacher in the Departamento de Bolívar, but after retiring, he began working more persistently. He is always available to work every day so he can make more money. His customer base consists of friends from his teaching days, relatives, recommended customers, and employees with good payment habits. This Kiva loan is his first with the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation. With the loan, he will buy nutritional products wholesale in cash, as well as seasonal merchandise of clothes, shoes, and small electrical appliance in order to make the most of his customer's high demand during the second half of the year. His goal is to continue increasing his sales so he can improve his quality of life. Policarpo really enjoys his shop's location, since it is in the epicenter of shopping in southern Barranquilla near the Atlético Junior's football stadium, Estadio Metropolitano.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying nutritional products wholesale and stocking seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: BUYING SOFT DRINKS, SNACKS, AND BASIC GRAINS TO SELL

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy materials such as cement, zinc sheeting, wood etc.

loans.name: G. S Jehova Es Mi Fortaleza Group

texts.es: El grupo Solidario Jehová Es Mi Fortaleza está conformado por Thelma y Josefa ambas, por lo que no es la primera vez que solicita financiamientos ya que es muy importante. Ellas han aprendido mucho con esta experiencia Thelma se dedica a la una pulpería, hace mas de 10 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que siempre está buscando la manera de mejorar sus ingresos y los de su familia en cambio su otra compañera Josefa se dedica a la venta de tortillas hace mas de 9 años que se dedica a esta actividad, siempre está pensando en invertir cada día más en inventario. El financiamiento que solicitan es para la compra de materia prima invertida en su negocio.
texts.en:
The ‘Jehovah is my Strength’ group is made up of Thelma and Josefa. It is important to note that this is not the first time they have asked for a loan. They learned a lot from this experience. Thelma has run a small grocery store for ten years, and she is always seeking ways to increase her income and that of her family. Josefa, on the other hand, has sold sold tortillas for nine years. She is always planning ways to find money to invest in the business. They plan to use the loan to invest in materials for their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a single mother of four children, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of her aged mother and some orphans. She owns a restaurant in Nakulabye selling all types of food, both African (like bananas, cassava, and potatoes), and Western (like chips and sausages). She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, rice, sacks of cassava and potatoes.  She buys foodstuffs from Nakulabye market and so incurs little transport costs to and from shopping.

Mary works from her home and so doesn’t pay rent for her business. She sells to all categories of people but on retail only. She works six days a week. Her business challenge is the rainy season because she works from a muddy place and so this hinders her customers to reach out to her.

Besides this food business she also gets additional income from rental rooms.  She has been in the hotel business for over ten years.

She is aspiring of improving her standards of living.   She decided to join MCDT because of the low interest charged.  Mary resides in and owns a three roomed house and the family has access to electricity but not to piped water.  Her monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: restocking restaurant with bananas, cassava, rice, and potatoes

loans.name: Hernan

texts.es:
El señor Hernán M. es una persona humilde vive en su comunidad Huayllapujru en la Provincia Tiraque del Departamento de Cochabamba.

El señor Hernán M. vive con su familia tiene un hijo es una persona joven con ganas de mejorar sus ingresos, su casa es de adobe (barro) con techo de paja el interior tiene revoque de barro, la actividad principal de Hernán M. es la agricultura. Produce papa, haba y cereales su producción es temporal  ósea que produce una vez al año. El préstamo que ha solicitado es para los insumos agrícolas como ser abono de gallina, semilla de papa y haba, esto con el objetivo de incrementar más su producción agrícola y mejorar sus actividades económicas.

El trabajo lo realiza es solo, en algunos casos con la ayuda de sus vecinos, los cuales lo consideran una persona sumamente trabajadora. Su mayor sueño es poder mejorar algún día las condiciones en las que vive, que lamentablemente son muy precarias.
texts.en:
Señor Hernán M. is an unassuming man who lives in the community of Huayllapujru, in the province of Tiraque, Cochabamba department. He lives with his family. His son is a young man who would love to increase his income. Their house is made of adobe with a thatched roof and the interior is plastered with mud. Hernán grows potatoes, beans, and cereal crops according to the season, so he harvests each crop once per year. The loan he is asking for will be used to buy agricultural supplies such as chicken fertilizer, seed potatoes and beans, in order to get better harvests and increase his income. Generally Hernán works alone, but sometimes he enlists the help of his neighbours who consider him a hardworking person. His greatest dream is to one day improve the conditions in which he lives, which, sadly, are very poor.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Manuel Jesus

texts.es:
Manuel de 39 años, el vive en el suburbio de Guayaquil, es fotógrafo y tiene dos hijos de 8 y 6 años. 

Y tiene varios años como fotógrafo, pero tuvo que seguir esta profesión por la falta de oportunidades, con el fin de mantener a su familia el tuvo que comprar una carama fotográfica y una computadora para digitalizar las fotos, poco a poco con ayuda de su esposa pudieron tener un local y ubicar un centro de fotografías. Ahora trabajan hasta en horarios nocturnos por la cantidad numerosa de clientes.
