loans.name: Noli

texts.en:
Noli C. is from the town of Pangal Norte, Echague. He is 42 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice to sell. He has been engaged in his business for over twenty years and earns approximately $340 per harvest for his activities.

In 2008, Noli joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Noli is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his 4th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated  to improve his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Maricon

texts.en:
Maricon H. is from the village of Bantay, Solana, Cagayan. She is 35 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she raises pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $50 a month for these activities.

Maricon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and the ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase medication for her livestock. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase medication for her livestock

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina D. is from the village of Calamagui, San Pablo. She is 40 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she sells street foods in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $80 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Gina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional products to sell on the street. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mamasabir

texts.en:
Mamasabir J. is a resident of Kadamjai, a nice town on the south of Kyrgyzstan. He is 43 years old, married, and has three daughters and a son.  The older daughter studies at university and the others are at school. Five years ago, with the initial investment of 10,000 KGS, Mamasabir and his wife started to grow rice. Selling some part of the harvest, Mamasabir makes about $195 per month.  That profit made it possible for him to save money and purchase a vehicle. With money received from this loan he wants to purchase two tons of mineral fertilizers which are needed for sowing rice. In the near future Mamasabir plans to celebrate his daughter’s wedding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused micro-finance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only micro-finance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer A. is from the village of Bagahabag, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 36 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $175 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jennifer joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Abdimitalip

texts.en:
Abdimitalip O. is a resident of Kadamjai, a nice town in the south of Kyrgyzstan.  He is 43 and married. He has two daughters, the first daughter studying at university and the second just graduated from school. 

In 1995, when the collective farms broke up, Abdimitalip was given a plot of land where he started to grow wheat. Then he decided to grow rice instead of wheat, because the profit from selling the rice is higher.  In this way he makes about $130 per month. That profit made it possible for him to save money and purchase a vehicle.  With money received from the loan he wants to purchase 1.5 tons of mineral fertilizers which are needed for getting a good harvest.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Boldu

texts.en:
Boldu N. is the resident of Kadamjai, a nice town on the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 46 years old and married. She has two sons and a daughter. The first son went to work in Russia, the daughter helps her mom with her business activity and the younger son studies at school. Boldu works as a cook and cleaner at a school. She also sells rice to make money. Almost all of the family members are engaged in the rice selling activity. Selling some part of the harvest, Boldu makes 6600 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase 1.5 tons of mineral fertilizers for sowing the rice. In the future she wants to purchase a vehicle for her son to start working as a taxi driver. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

loans.name: Erlita

texts.en:
Erlita D. is from the village of Agay-ayan, Gingoog City. She is 54 years old. Erlita is widowed and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Erlita owns & operates a business venture making & selling steam-cake and ice fruit candy in the local community. Erlita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Erlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Erlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients & working capital. Erlita is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she has for sale. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Erlita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Jinky

texts.en:
Jinky T. is from the village of Santan, Cabantian, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 38 years old. Jinky is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Jinky owns & operates a business making & selling meats for different meals and running a mini store in the local community. Jinky has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Jinky joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jinky has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Jinky is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Jinky from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Urpiya's Group

texts.en:
Urpiya M. is the leader of the group. She is 36 and divorced. She has a daughter and a son, both of whom are at school. Urpiya works in the notary office and also sews national cloth and dressmaking supplies. Urpiya started to work as a notary sixteen years ago, and receives a salary in the amount of 4000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to start repairing her house. She needs money to purchase cement, bricks and other building materials. In the future, Urpiya plans to open a sewing workshop.

Aidan A., 54, is married. She has four daughters and a son. The first son is a shepherd, the second works in Russia, the third serves in the army and the fourth son is a farmer. Aidan and her husband have been breeding livestock for a long time; they have about 70 farm animals. With money received from the loan Aidan wants to purchase 250 kg of feed for livestock.

Zulaiho P. is the treasurer of the group. She is 38 years old and married. She has a daughter and two sons, all of whom are at school. Zulaiho is a dish seller and her husband works in the police department. Zulaiho started her business activities two years ago, with the initial investment of 5000 soms, and now she earns 3000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase a variety of dishes to increase the turnover of her business. In the future Zulaiho plans to expand her business and to save money to be able to give her children a good education. 

Bermet A., 30, is married. She has two daughters. The first daughter is at school and the second is not yet old enough for school. Bermet works in the notary office and her husband works in the police department. Bermet earns 5000 soms per month. She applied for the loan, because she needs money to purchase carpets at a low price. She plans to resell the carpets to make some money. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). loans.use: To purchase building materials.

loans.name: Candido

texts.en:
Candido C. Jr. is from the village of Cabanatian, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. He is 32 years old. Candido is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Candido owns & operates a business making & selling specialty food products like home-made sausage, or longganisa, in the local community. Candido has been engaged in his business for over 6 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Candido joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Candido has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Candido is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items or machines to expand the product offering. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Candido from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase new items or machines to expand product offering.

loans.name: Shamshad's Group

texts.en:
Shamshad is a  resident in the city of Multan, the fourth largest city of Pakistan. She lives in a three room brick house with her family. Her husband runs a thread selling business. He supplies thread to different thread sellers to earn an income. Shamshad does embroidery work to financially support her family. She is very competent in her work and gets regular orders. 

Shamshad has five children: four sons and a daughter. All of them are illiterate except her daughter who is getting a religious education. Her first three sons work and one son stays at home. One of her sons has a business making bed-sheets A second son does labor work and the third is working in a factory. 

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her embroidery business. With the loan amount she will buy embroider material such as beads, clothes, sketches and colored thread in bulk and improve her embroidery business.  This is her first loan cycle with MFI. She is hopeful that this investment will help her business grow.

loans.use: Purchase embroideyr material in bulk to improve her embroidey business

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros T. is from the village of Cabantian, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 65 years old. Milagros is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Milagros owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Milagros has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Milagros joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Milagros has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Milagros is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Milagros from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

loans.name: Salam

texts.en:
Salam is a 46 years old married woman with three children. Salam has been selling linens and bed sheets since 2005. This is Salam’s eighth loan with Al Majmoua and she is a client with a perfect pay back history. Salam helps her husband earn the family income especially in the present financial and economical crisis. She believes that one hand never claps, and that husbands and wives must unite together for their families’ benefit. 

Salam is requesting a Loan from Al Majmoua, in order to buy new linens and bed sheets for the autumn season. Her dream is to move to a bigger shop and start a wholesale trade.

loans.use: To buy new linens and bed sheets for the autumn season

loans.name: Michil

texts.en: Michil is a 36 year old man from Lebanon who is married with 3 kids. Michil owns a restaurant in his village which is popular in its tasty food and cleanliness. This is the second time Michil requests a loan from Al Majmoua.  Michil is requesting a Loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy a chicken roasted machine. Michil seeks perfection in his work. He has used his saved money to repair his restaurant after a big fire took place in it and ruined everything he had. Michil hopes to own a big restaurant in a tourist area since Lebanon is a touristic country, which everyone likes to visit.

loans.use: To buy a chicken roasting machine

loans.name: Mirgul's Group

texts.en:
Mirgul O. is the leader of the group.  She is 31 and married. She has two daughters, both of them are at school. Mirgul sells clothes on the market and her husband works as a taxi driver. Mirgul started her business activity two years ago with the initial investment of 15000 soms and now she makes 12000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase different clothes of a good quality to become more competitive on the market. In the future she plans to expand her business and improve the living conditions.

Nurzada H. is the treasurer of the group. She is 23 and married. She has two daughters and two sons, all of them are preschool age (under 7).  Nurzada is engaged in cattle breeding, the resells cattle on the market and her husband works in construction.  Nurzada started to breed cattle four years ago with the initial investment of 10000 soms and now she makes 9000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase cattle for breeding.  In the future she plans to start building a new house.

Batma B., 28, is married.  She has a son and a daughter, both of them are preschool age.  Batma has just started her business at the marke. She sells clothes and the initial investment in that business was 50000 soms. She makes 11500 soms per month.  Her husband works in the police department.  When he is free, he tries to help Batma at the market. Batma applied for the loan because she wants her business to be more competitive and needs money to purchase clothes of a good quality. 

Elnura M., 26, is married. She has a daughter and a son, the daughter is at school and her son is not yet at school.  Two years ago with the initial investment of 30000 soms Elnura started to sell clothes on the market. She makes 15000 soms per month.  That profit made it possible for her to purchase household appliances.  With money received from the loan Elnura wants to purchase goods of a good quality in order to attract more clients.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. loans.use: to purchase clothes of a good quality

Remedios B. is from the village of Caban. She is 55 years old. Remedios is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Remedios owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

loans.name: Randy

texts.en:
Randy T. is from the village of Agay-ayan, Gingoog City. He is 39 years old. Randy is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Randy owns & operates a bakeshop, selling a variety of confectioneries such cookies and cakes, in the local community. loans.name: Bufumbe Development Group-Lugazi

texts.en:
34 year old M. Bena has taken steps over the last 7 years that have made the chances of success in her restaurant business sky rocket. Her optimism has always been sky high and she has never wavered, for 7 years so far. Her restaurant business profits have helped her shoulder her responsibilities, especially family-related. In a week, she makes 35,000 shillings as profits. She also operates a retail shop business in the same town of Bufumbe in Lugazi.

M. has 8 children, 7 of whom are in school. With this loan, she wants to purchase more food, in bulk, for her restaurant. Foods such as sweet potatoes, yams, rice, beans, maize flour and cassava are high on her shopping list.

loans.use: The purchase of more foods in bulk for her restaurant.

loans.name: Kalsoom's Group

texts.en:
Kalsoom lives in the historic city called Multan, in Pakistan. She works part time in an embroidering clothes making business to financially support her husband. She is basically a housewife but takes time out after managing the household chores for her embroidery business.  
Her husband is a very skillful man. He has a business making & selling of bed-sheets. He has been doing this work for over seven years. 

Kalsoom is the mother of seven children, three sons and four daughters. Her eldest son helps his father in his bed-sheets business. Kalsoom has transferred her art of embroidery to her daughters who are now earning good income from their quality work. Kalsoom has decided to convert her part time business into full-time to better generate income. She has applied for a loan from Asasah for purchasing an embroidery machine, which will help her make more money and to fulfill orders on time. This is her second loan cycle with ASASAH. In her first loan cycle she helped her daughters start their embroidery business. 

She hopes that she will be able to become successful in her business with the help of this investment.

loans.use: To purchase an embroidery machine for embroidery business.

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en:
Rustam M. has been able to improve his family’s financial situation thanks to the excellent care that he has given his animals. Now Rustam is requesting a loan from IMON International to purchase more calves to raise. Their eventual sale will yield additional profits that will used to support his family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.name: Kassem

texts.en:
Kassem, a 27-year-old single man from Lebanon, has worked as a house painter since 2000. Kassem really enjoys his work and believes that success in it requires special professional talents, something most of his clients assure him that he has.

A hard worker; he is requesting his second loan from Al Majmoua to buy materials necessary for his work and to continue building his dream house which he states is going to be heaven on earth. Kassem's poor financial situation has limited his ability to promote his work experience, and he hopes this loan will remedy the situation and that one day he can open a painting equipment store.

loans.use: To buy necessary materials for his work

loans.name: Gyaviira

texts.en:
Gyaviira B. is 36 years old and lives in the town of Nyendo in the Masaka region of Uganda.  He is married and has 4 children.  All of his children are currently in school.  Gyaviira has a business owning a computer shop dealing with internet, which he has had for less than one year.         

To help expand his business, Gyaviira has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more computers and tables.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Gyaviira hopes to generate greater profits and to educate his children.  In the future, Gyaviira hopes to expand his computer business.

texts.en:
Luna C. is from the village of Lunao, Gingoog City. She is 47 years old. Luna is married and has 9 adult-aged children. To make a living, Luna owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Luna has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Luna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Luna is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Luna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Nasira's Group

texts.en:
Nasira lives in the city of Multan, famous in Pakistan for its history. Nasira has spent most of her life in Multan. She is married to D. A. who runs a business making and selling bedsheets.

She has given birth to five children, four sons and a daughter. Her daughter is illiterate while her eldest son also left his education after 8th standard (grade). They both have started doing work to financially support the family. Her daughter does embroidery and her son works in a factory. Nasira’s younger children are getting their education.

Nasira also does embroidery work for her neighborhood clients. She wants to expand business for herself and her daughter, so that’s why she has applied for a loan from Asasah.  This is the first time she is getting a loan from any MFI. With the loan amount she will buy embroidery material such as clothing, beads and colored thread in bulk which will help them to complete more embroidered dresses and for generating good profit on it.

She hopes that this investment will be profitable for both of them and they will be able to improve the financial conditions of their family.

loans.use: Purchase embroidery material for improving embroidery business

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha N. is 32 years old and lives in the town of Lukaya in the Masaka region of Uganda.  She is married and has 5 children.  Aisha has a retail shop business dealing in cold drinks and household items, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Aisha has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more drinks and to buy a fridge.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Aisha hopes to generate greater profits and take good care of her children by giving them a better education.  In the future, Aisha hopes to maintain her business.

Having repaid her previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional materials needed, she is now requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to invest in expanding the business. This will be Meliza's second loan from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

loans.name: Buyanja Promotion A, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
Hard working Sharotte K. has been operating a new garment business selling women's suits, wedding gowns and more for 20 years in Buyanja town. This determined and innovative lady has by all standards tried to maintain the business that she started with little capital when she was a housewife.

Her main business limitation is having a small stock of clothing, so she is requesting this loan to purchase a greater variety of garments that will attract more customers. The additional profits from an expanded line will enable her to meet her family's expenses as she considers starting up a poultry business.

Sharotte belongs to a group of members who hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

Hellen is 39 years old and is married to a major in the army. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bar and install a DStv (Digital Satellite Television) for football channels.

texts.en:

This is the first time Wafaa has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. She will use the loan to open a new clothing shop of her own to improve her income and her parent’s living standard.

Wafaa is well-known in her area. She believes her business will be visited by many neighbors and relatives in addition to passersby who will find the good quality of product she has. She hopes to own a bigger boutique in the future.

loans.use: To open a new clothing shop

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita E. is 49 years old and married with eight children. She lives with her husband in the province of Antique in the Philippines.

For almost four years, Angelita has been engaged in hog fattening. She is hard-working, determined, and dedicated. She would like to receive a loan to purchase additional piglets, feeds, vitamins and other supplies.

As a very active member since 2007 of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Angelita has been a model member, demonstrating regular attendance at weekly meetings and steady repayments on previous loans. With the help of ASHI, she has already funded the college education of three of her children.
 
Angelita’s dream is for her other children to complete college. Additionally, she hopes to continue her hog-fattening business as a sustainable livelihood to support her family, to reach her goals in life, and to have a happy family.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets, feeds, vitamins and other supplies

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija is a married woman with six children: five boys and a girl. Two attend school while others are adults. She rents a house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Hadija has been running her business of selling fruit and coconuts for the last fifteen years. She sells from home and at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, Hadija wants to purchase more coconuts, bananas and mangoes. She hopes that someday she will open her own stall. Her main aim of working with Yehu is to access loans and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more coconuts, bananas and mangoes to sell

Getrude, aged 53 years, is a happily married lady of five children and has been in the produce business for over twenty years. She grows food crops like beans, maize, coffee and bananas in Buyanja, Rukungiri, which has always earned her 300,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis.

This loan is to help Getrude purchase manure for her plantation as she looks at diversifying her business.  This is because she did not have sound capital at the beginning. This will give her a free ticket to earn more revenue and cater for her family’s basic needs and also acquire a self-sustaining life as she hopes to open up a big supplies store to sell her produce.

texts.en:
Shadi is a 37-year-old married man living in Lebanon with his wife and four children. Shadi has worked in a few occupations -- trading charcoal and wood, decorating glass with sand, and as a farmer -- for 13 years. Shadi believes that, in Lebanon, you have to work at multiple things in order to insure a good living for your family. 

This is Shadi’s fifth loan cycle with Al Majmoua and he proved to be a trusted person. This time Shadi is requesting a loan in order to buy a pickup for his business so he can do his work in an easier and faster way. 

Shadi hopes to widen his work in all sectors and benefit his family members through working with him.

loans.name: Ginalyn

texts.en:
Ginalyn D. has been able to sustain her fishing business through the previous loan she received from ASHI. She has repaid the whole amount of the loan she received, and the small profit she earned has been added to her husband’s income from being a fisherman. With that, she has been able to pay for the education of her only son as well as for their other basic needs, allowing them to enjoy life in a simple way.

Ginalyn would like to request a larger loan for the sustainability and growth of her previous business as well as for her new venture -- buying and selling fish. 

Ginalyn is determined to improve her business as well as the life of her family. Knowing that she can access financial support through loans has given her courage and faith that someday, her child will graduate from college and be ready to face his own life.

Ginalyn’s business has been very helpful in achieving her family's dreams. Her greatest hope is that her family will be able to have a decent way of life. Her long-term goals are to invest and build a better house for the family and to have full-fledged fish farm someday.

loans.use: For sustainability and growth of her fishing business and support her secondary business of buying and selling of fish

loans.name: Amna's Group

texts.en:
Amna, a 55-year-old lady, is married with two children. She resides in a city called Multan, which is famous for its history, in Pakistan. 

She has raised a son and a daughter and made them qualified in their own fields. Her son is involved in making and selling bed sheets. He got full training from one of the bed-sheets production factories and now he uses his skills for his own business. Her daughter has received training in embroidery skills from her. She and Amna now help each other in preparing embroidered dresses to complete orders of the customers. 

Her husband, 58 years of age, is a driver by trade. He drives a rickshaw (a three-wheeled motor vehicle) and works hard to put three meals on the table of his family. 

They all are very hardworking people. They all make effort in improving their financial condition and the living standard of their family as well. 

Amna is in her third loan cycle with Asasah. In the previous two loans, she maintained good credit behavior and never missed a meeting. This time, she has applied for a loan for her embroidery business. With the loan amount, she will buy embroidery materials, such as cloth, beads and colored thread, in bulk and make improvements to her business.

loans.name: Tasleem's Group

texts.en:
Tasleem is 35 years old and married with four children. She resides in a city called Multan, which is famous for its history, in Pakistan. She is an uneducated lady who couldn’t study because her parents were not in a position to afford her education expenses, but she has a God-gifted talent hidden inside, which she knew when she got involved in the business of embroidering dresses.
  
She steadily grew her business and her customers acknowledge her skills. She started preparing embroidered dresses for her relatives first, but later on she introduced her skills to her neighbors as well and they are now her good customers. She has been doing this work for over 10 years. She has a talent of making any embroidered art she sees the first time and making it her own. She generates approximately 5000 Pakistan rupees from her business, which helps her to pay for the utilities.
 
Her husband's name is M. S.. He has been involved in a dairy business for past 10 years. He has a buffalo at his home and gets milk from her and sells it to different milk shops.  

Tasleem is in her fourth loan cycle with Asasah. She has maintained good credit behavior in the past three years and never missed a meeting. In this year, she has applied for a loan for her husband. With the loan amount, he will buy another buffalo, which will help him increase his milk-selling business.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo for the dairy business

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane M., from the village of Balzain West, Tuguegarao City, is 46 years old. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Jane owns & operates a general retail store.  The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste to the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mary Jane joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her store's product offering. This loan will be Mary Jane's 1st loan from ASKI. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a married woman with five children: two boys and three girls, all of whom attend school. Her husband is employed and he contributes to his family's needs. 

She has been operating her retail shop and a chemist shop for the last four years, selling to the neighboring community and passersby. With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings loan, she wants to purchase a bundle of maize flour, wheat flour, rice and medications for her chemist. She has no other source of income. 

Eunice faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She decided to work with Yehu so as to improve her business. 

She rents a house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of maize flour, wheat flour, rice and medications for her pharmacy
